  physical_appearance: This is a black-and-white portrait photograph. It features a group of soldiers in uniform. They are gathered and sitting casually under the shade on the ground. Most of them are faced towards the camera. In the background
 there are several small buildings seen. The photograph is slightly faded
 and stained along the left side.

  sgcool_label_text: These photographs belong to part of a collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The Chan Phui Kong collection forms part of a larger collection gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012)
 who was like Chan
 a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee
 which date from the late 1980s to early 2000s. \r\n\r\nForce 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

metadata.sgcool_label_text:
These photographs belong to part of a collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The Chan Phui Kong collection forms part of a larger collection gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was like Chan, a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the late 1980s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.
